message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Sinus node dysfunction suggests dysfunction in the automaticity of the sinoatrial node, which is influenced by HCN channels. The gene "X" codes for this specific ion channel. L-type voltage-dependent calcium channels regulate myocardial contractility, while fast delayed rectifier voltage-dependent K+ channels control the repolarization phase of the cardiac action potential. Stretch-activated cationic channels are important for mechanotransduction, but not specifically related to sinoatrial node dysfunction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Sinus node dysfunction suggests a problem with the automaticity of the sinoatrial node. HCN channels play a key role in the automaticity of the sinoatrial node as they are the first ion channels to be activated immediately after hyperpolarization. Gene "X" codes for HCN channels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The question describes a mutation in a gene responsible for the automaticity of the sinoatrial node, which suggests HCN-channels. The description of the ion channel being activated immediately after hyperpolarization also supports HCN-channels, as they are activated by hyperpolarization. L-type voltage-dependent calcium channels are responsible for the plateau phase of the cardiac action potential, Fast delayed rectifier (IKr) voltage-dependent K+ channels repolarize the cardiac action potential, and Stretch-activated cationic channels are not specific to cardiac tissue.

We refer to the "Ion channel" section of the Wikipedia article on "Sinoatrial node" for help. The ion channel that is most important in automaticity of the sinoatrial node is the hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated (HCN) channel. The gene "X" codes for this channel, which is the first ion channel activated after hyperpolarization.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The gene “X” codes for HCN-channels (hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated channels), which are the most important ion channels responsible for the automaticity of the sinoatrial node.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. HCN-channels are responsible for pacemaker function in the sinoatrial node and are activated immediately after hyperpolarization. The other options are not primarily responsible for pacemaker function in the sinoatrial node.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The question asks for the ion channel coded by the mutated gene "X", which is the most important ion channel for the automaticity of the sinoatrial node and is activated immediately after hyperpolarization. This describes HCN-channels (Hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated channels), which are found in the sinoatrial node and play a crucial role in generating the pacemaker current.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The gene "X" codes for HCN-channels, which are the most important ion channel underlying the automaticity of the sinoatrial node. HCN channels are activated immediately after hyperpolarization and their mutation can lead to sinus node dysfunction, resulting in syncope and dizziness. The other options are not related to the automaticity of the sinoatrial node.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The automaticity of the sinoatrial node is conducted by the HCN-channels which open after hyperpolarization. Therefore, the mutated gene “X” is most likely coding for HCN-channels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The gene "X" codes for HCN channels, which are the ion channels responsible for the automaticity of the sinoatrial node. They are also referred to as pacemaker channels because they establish the rhythm of the heartbeats. Dysfunction in these channels can lead to syncope, dizziness, and other cardiac symptoms. None of the other options are responsible for automaticity in the sinoatrial node.
